metadata.title: Fundamentals of Penetration Testing
metadata.prerequisite: CSC 158 (Introduction to Cybersecurity: Ethical Hacking) with grade of C or better

description.catalog: This course will explore the application of penetration testing methodologies, tools, and techniques to identify and exploit security vulnerabilities in networks, systems, and applications. Students will learn ethical hacking approaches following industry-standard frameworks and best practices.
description.expanded: Emphasis is placed on understanding penetration testing phases from reconnaissance through reporting. Students complete hands-on labs that progressively build skills in OSINT, social engineering, vulnerability assessment, web application testing, network exploitation, Active Directory attacks, wireless security, cloud security, and automation scripting.

purpose.why: This course provides essential cybersecurity skills for careers in penetration testing, red team operations, and security consulting. You'll learn how to identify vulnerabilities before attackers do, perform comprehensive security assessments, and communicate findings professionally. These skills are crucial for CompTIA PenTest+ certification, OSCP preparation, and cybersecurity analyst roles.
purpose.beyond: Beyond technical skills, you'll develop critical thinking for security analysis, ethical decision-making under legal constraints, and the ability to communicate complex technical findings to both technical and non-technical audiences—skills essential for any cybersecurity professional.

slos: Implement advanced methods to gain access to protected devices
Use scripts to automate pen testing attacks
Create a clear, concise and complete professional report of penetration testing findings

phases.title: Phase 1: Foundations & Planning (Weeks 1-2)
phases.description: Establish penetration testing fundamentals and ethical/legal framework

topics: Types of penetration assessments (black box, white box, gray box)
Industry standards and frameworks (PTES, OWASP, NIST)
weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 1; PTES Technical Guidelines; OWASP Testing Guide (Introduction)
weeks.notes: Focus on establishing ethical boundaries and lab environment

weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 2; Sample SOW templates
assignments: Lab 2: Scope Document & ROE Creation (12.5 pts)

phases.title: Phase 2: Reconnaissance & Social Engineering (Weeks 3-4)
phases.description: Master information gathering and human-based attack vectors

topics: OSINT sources and tools (Maltego, theHarvester, Shodan)
weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 3 (Sections 3.1-3.3); OSINT Framework documentation
assignments: Discussion 3: Ethical boundaries in OSINT (3 pts)
weeks.notes: First major assignment; focus on passive reconnaissance

topics: Social engineering attack vectors (phishing, vishing, smishing)
weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 4; 'The Art of Deception' excerpts

phases.title: Phase 3: Vulnerability Assessment & Web Application Testing (Weeks 5-7)
phases.description: Identify and exploit web application vulnerabilities

weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 3 (Sections 3.4-3.6); CVSS v3.1 Specification
assignments: Discussion 5: Scanning vs. pen testing (3 pts)
Discussion 6: Recent web breach analysis (3 pts)
Lab 6: SQL Injection and XSS Exploitation (12.5 pts)

weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 6 (Sections 6.5-6.8); OWASP API Security Top 10
assignments: Lab 7: Authentication Bypass & API Testing (12.5 pts)
Assignment 3: Complete Web Application Assessment (15 pts)

phases.title: Phase 4: Network Penetration Testing (Weeks 8-10)
phases.description: Attack external and internal networks, culminating in midterm exam

weeks.notes: Take-home midterm exam (1 week to complete)

topics: Active Directory architecture and attack surface
weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 9 (Sections 9.3-9.5); Active Directory Security blog
assignments: Lab 10: Active Directory Attack Chain (12.5 pts)

phases.title: Phase 5: Specialized Testing (Weeks 11-15)
phases.description: Wireless, exploitation, pivoting, IoT/OT, and cloud security

topics: Wireless security protocols (WEP, WPA, WPA2, WPA3)

assignments: Quiz 11: Metasploit and privilege escalation (10 pts)

topics: Double pivoting to access segmented networks
weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 9 (Sections 9.10-9.12); SSH tunneling guides
assignments: Lab 13: Network Pivoting and Tunneling (12.5 pts)

topics: Common IoT vulnerabilities (hardcoded credentials, firmware issues)
weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 8; OWASP IoT Top 10
assignments: Quiz 13: IoT, OT, SCADA security (10 pts)
Lab 14: IoT and SCADA Assessment (12.5 pts)

topics: Cloud service models (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS) security
weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 7; AWS/Azure security documentation

phases.title: Phase 6: Automation & Final Project (Weeks 16-17)
phases.description: Scripting automation and comprehensive final deliverables

weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 11; 'Black Hat Python' excerpts
assignments: Discussion 16: Ethics of automated tools (3 pts)
Assignment 6: Custom Penetration Testing Tool (15 pts)

weeks.readings: CompTIA PenTest+ Ch. 10; SANS report writing guidelines; PTES reporting
assignments: Discussion 17: Best practices in reporting (3 pts)
FINAL PROJECT: Comprehensive Penetration Test (250 pts)
weeks.notes: Final week - all capstone deliverables due

workload.note: Time commitment varies by week. Assignment weeks require 14-16 hours. Non-assignment weeks require 10-12 hours. Final project weeks require 15-20 hours.

components.description: Hands-on penetration testing lab exercises with documentation
Knowledge-based quizzes on key concepts and techniques
Weekly reflection posts and peer engagement
Major penetration testing projects and scenarios
Multi-phase penetration test demonstrating course mastery
Professional penetration testing report and presentation

grading.bonusOpportunities: Up to 60 points extra credit: Bug bounty participation (20 pts), Security conference (15 pts), Tool tutorial (10 pts), CTF competition (15 pts)
grading.passingGrade: C (70%) required for Cybersecurity majors and to progress to advanced courses

policies.attendance: Lab sessions are strongly recommended for hands-on practice. Remote students should complete labs asynchronously. Students who actively participate in labs perform significantly better.
policies.lateWork: Standard: 10% deduction (0-24hrs), 25% (24-48hrs), 50% (48-72hrs), 0 points after 72hrs. Exceptions: Midterm/Final exams not accepted late. Final project: 10% per day, max 3 days. Labs: max 1 week late with penalties.
policies.makeupWork: Quizzes cannot be made up. Labs and assignments can be completed late with penalty. Contact instructor within 48 hours of emergency for consideration.
policies.academicIntegrity: All work must be your own. Discussing concepts is allowed; copying reports/code is not. AI assistance (ChatGPT, Copilot) must be disclosed for any assignment. Plagiarism = 0 on assignment + possible course failure. Unauthorized testing of systems outside lab environment is strictly prohibited and may result in legal consequences.
policies.collaboration: Collaboration on labs during class time is encouraged. Sharing of tools and techniques is welcome. Submitting identical reports or exploits is not acceptable. All deliverables must be individual work.

successTips: Set up virtual lab environment in Week 1 - delays compound quickly
Practice in your home lab regularly - hands-on experience is crucial
Start assignments early - penetration tests take longer than expected
Document everything - screenshots and notes are essential for reports
Attend lab sessions - instructor guidance accelerates learning
Join online communities (TryHackMe, HackTheBox) for additional practice
Read tool documentation - understanding tools deeply improves effectiveness
Focus on methodology over memorization - frameworks guide real engagements
Test ethically - only on authorized systems in controlled environments
Build professional reporting habits early - documentation is half the job
